This theorem, `RatFunc.denom_zero`, states that for any type `K`, which is a field, the denominator of the zero rational function (`RatFunc 0`) is equal to `1`. In other words, in any field, the denominator of the rational function representing zero is normalized to be the monic polynomial `1`.

This is the Infinite Pigeonhole Principle. Given two types `Î²` and `Î±`, and a function `f` from `Î²` to `Î±`, if the cardinality of `Î²` is greater than or equal to `â„µâ‚€` (the smallest infinite cardinal, equivalent to the cardinality of natural numbers), and the cardinality of `Î±` is less than the cofinality of the ordinal corresponding to the cardinality of `Î²`, then there exists an element `a` of `Î±` such that the cardinality of the preimage of `a` under `f` is equal to the cardinality of `Î²`. Essentially, if we have infinitely many "pigeons" and less "holes", at least one hole must contain infinitely many pigeons.

name: Ordinal.infinite_pigeonhole
docString: This is the Infinite Pigeonhole Principle. Given two types `Î²` and `Î±`, and a function `f` from `Î²` to `Î±`, if the cardinality of `Î²` is greater than or equal to `â„µâ‚€` (the smallest infinite cardinal, equivalent to the cardinality of natural numbers), and the cardinality of `Î±` is less than the cofinality of the ordinal corresponding to the cardinality of `Î²`, then there exists an element `a` of `Î±` such that the cardinality of the preimage of `a` under `f` is equal to the cardinality of `Î²`. Essentially, if we have infinitely many "pigeons" and less "holes", at least one hole must contain infinitely many pigeons.

`sqrt z` is the square root of an integer `z`. If `z` is positive, it returns the largest
integer `r` such that `r * r â‰¤ n`. If it is negative, it returns `0`. For example, `sqrt (-1) = 0`,
`sqrt 1 = 1`, `sqrt 2 = 1`
